PROFESSOR: Coulombs
force law can

be the basis for estimating
the net charge on an object.

Conservation of
charge and Gauss's law

are also the basis for
the measurement of charge.

Coulomb's force law states that
a particle or object carrying

a net charge, q2, in an electric
field due to a second charge,

q1, experiences a
force proportional

to the product of the charges
and inversely proportional

to the square of the
distance r between.

Charges of the same
polarity repel.

In this demonstration,
the particles

are air-filled balloons of
the variety used at parties.

They can be charged by
rubbing them with a dry cloth.

They repel each other
because they've been
charged to the same polarity.

Let's use measurements of
the separation distance

and the weight of the balloon
to approximate the charge that's

been left on one
of the balloons.

The threads that have
been used to suspend them
are tied at a common point.

We can measure the
vertical distance l

between the height of the
balloons and the point
where the threads are tied.

We can also measure the
distance r between the balloons.

The balloons are not
all that small compared
to these distances.

However, for the purpose
of estimating the charge,

we'll represent them as point
charges and point masses.

There are three forces
acting on the right balloon,

the downward vertical
force of gravity,

the balloon mass times the
acceleration of gravity g,

the horizontal coulomb
force of repulsion,

and the tension
supplied by the thread.

To have the tension
of the thread

balance the gravitational
and electric forces,

the ratio of the coulomb force
to the gravitational force

must be equal to the
ratio of half the distance

between the balloons, r over
2, the vertical distance

from the balloon to
where the threat is tied.

If we assume that the
balloons are equally charged,

we can express the
coulomb force in terms

of the spacing between balloons
r and the desired charge q.

This expression
can be solved for q

as a function of the
quantities that we can measure.

Having measured the balloon
mass m, the spacing r,

and the height l,
we can deduce q.

First, we weigh a
typical balloon.

The mass m of this balloon
is 0.73 grams in MKS units.

The gravitational
acceleration is
9.8 meters per second squared.

The spacing between
balloon centers
is about 50 centimeters.

It's not possible to put
the meter stick close

to the balloons
without there being
attracted to Professor Zahn.
His body is a good conductor.

The charges on the balloons
induce image charges

of opposite polarity
on conducting surfaces
to which they're attracted.
The height l is roughly 1 meter.

Finally, the permittivity
of free space

is 8.85 times 10 to the
minus 12 ferads per meter.

Evaluation gives a charge q
of about 220 nanocoulombs.

Conservation of
charge and Gauss's law

can also be used to deduce
the charge on the balloons.

This will be done by putting
the balloon inside a conducting

enclosure and measuring
the charge induced
on the enclosure.

Note that this induced
charge is opposite
in sign to that of the balloon.

This image charge is just that
responsible for attracting

the balloons to any
essentially grounded conductor
in its vicinity.

By making this metal enclosure,
which is called a Faraday cage,

enclose the charge, we
make all of the field

lines from the balloon charge
terminate on the surrounding
walls.

The Faraday cage is insulated
from a surrounding grounded

shield and itself
connected to ground

through the low impedance
of an integrator.

The shield is necessary
to prevent field lines

from outside charges
terminating on the cage

such as from Professor Zahn's
having walked on the carpet.

Because of the enclosure is
itself essentially grounded,

there is little electric field
between it and its shield.

The integral form of
charge conservation

shows how the charge
induced on the Faraday cage

is related to the current
i to the integrator.

The surface S encloses
the cage completely
and cuts through the wire.

The only contribution to the
integral of the current density

is where the wire passes
through the surface
and is the current i.

Because the charge on the
outside of the Faraday cage

is 0, the net charge in
the volume V, enclosed

by this surface is the negative
of that brought inside the cage
as the balloon is introduced.

Thus, the current
through the wire

is the time rate of change
of the charge introduced

into the enclosure
with the balloon.

If the balloon is finally
completely enclosed

by the cage, then the
final value of this charge
is just that on the balloon.

This is true, even
if the balloon

makes no electrical contact
with the Faraday cage.

The integrator is made from
an operational amplifier.

And the integrated
signal could be
displayed on an oscilloscope.

Instead, we'll use an
integrating electrometer
in coulomb measurement mode.

It's designed to
display the charge that

would account for the integral
of the current into its input.

The shapes of the Faraday
cage and grounded shield
do not matter.

In our experiment,
the Faraday cage

is a wastepaper-basket-sized
rectangular aluminum box.

And the surrounding
shield is a metal screen.

By now, one of our
balloons is broken.

But with new balloons
and a renewed charge,

the spacing looks to be
about what we had before.

Here's what happens when
we insert the balloon
in the Faraday cage.
Watch the meter too.

Our charge
conservation statement

can be used to see that
it makes no difference

to the measurement
whether the balloon makes

physical and electrical
contact with the inner box.

From the dial settings
on the top scale,

a full-scale
deflection has a charge
of minus 1,000 nanocoulombs.

The measured charge is
220 or 230 nanocoulombs.

Let's see what we get
for the other balloon.

The reading is about the
same, about 220 nanocoulombs.

Remember, from our
force experiment,
we estimated 220 nanocoulombs.

Of course, given the
informality of our experiments,

this agreement is
somewhat fortuitous.

Both the electromechanical
and Faraday cage measurements

that we have illustrated
can be made very precise.

Here, we've illustrated
how Coulomb's force

law, the law of charge
conservation, and Gauss's law

can also be used to
make rough estimates.

When the balloon is
removed, the meter reading
almost goes back to 0.

Apparently, the
charge is essentially
removed with the balloon.

What happens to the
charge on the balloon

if it's broken while in the
Faraday cage and then removed?

We've used scotch tape to
hold the balloon together.

Professor Zahn feels that most
of the balloon was removed.
The charge was not.
